abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, with negligible institutional development impacts,
            although sustainability is likely, but both performances by
            the Bank and Borrower are also rated unsatisfactory.
            Significant lessons address the following. The development
            of a detailed operational strategy between several countries
            is a daunting effort under any circumstance, further
            aggravated when differences in power, wealth and political
            systems exist. It is thus suggested not to spend substantial
            resources in developing detailed strategies, neither
            specific studies with broad objectives due to the
            difficulties of often divergent opinions. Such divergence
            also creates difficulties, particularly to Global
            Environment Facility (GEF) operations, where emphasis is on
            the need for substantial cofinancing. Moreover, the
            responsibility of the project unit in implementing certain
            activities, would have better been implemented by
            country-level line agencies, such as the countries'
            Ministries of Agriculture/Environment or National Hydromet,
            so as to enhance country ownership, and strengthen national
            institutions. However, the project did validate an
            underlying assumption of the Aral Sea Basin Program: while
            restoring the Aral Sea to its former size and productivity
            will not be possible, it is feasible though to recreate much
            of the lost value by restoring wetlands in the deltas of the
            Amu and Syr Darya Rivers, determined by the successful
            restoration of Lake Sudoche. Notwithstanding, lessons
            emphasize that the design of regional programs would be
            better approached by separating projects and activities,
            into efforts at the national level, consistent with regional
            goals and coordination.
